questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute loss of vision in the right eye over the last 24 hours. He has noticed progressive bilateral loss of central vision over the last year. During this time, he has had difficulty reading the newspaper and watching television. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/60 in the left eye and 20/200 in the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Tonometry shows an intraocular pressure of 18 mm Hg in the right eye and 20 mm Hg in the left eye. Anterior segment examination is unremarkable. Fundoscopic examination shows subretinal fluid and small hemorrhages with grayish-green discoloration in the macular area in the right eye, and multiple drusen in the left eye with retinal pigment epithelial changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Etanercept is a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor used in the treatment of systemic inflammatory illnesses like rheumatoid arthritis. It has no role in the treatment of wet AMD yet. However, there are ongoing investigations that test the use intravitreal TNF-alpha inhibitors for the treatment of vascular and neovascular retinal diseases (e.g., wet AMD).

B) INCORRECT:

Thermal laser photocoagulation (retinal photocoagulation) can be used to coagulate the abnormal choroidal neovascular membrane in wet AMD. However, laser photocoagulation can also damage the overlying retina and may result in a permanent blind spot. Newer options with better efficacy and safety profiles are available and should be attempted first.

C) CORRECT:

Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitors (e.g., ranibizumab, bevacizumab) delivered via intravitreal injection are the first-line treatment for wet AMD. These substances inhibit the growth of new, friable blood vessels in the choriocapillaris, which are prone to bleeding and leaking. Second-line treatment options for wet AMD include photodynamic therapy and laser photocoagulation. Smoking cessation, hypertension control, and antioxidant vitamin supplementation are recommended for both dry and wet AMD.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

Subretinal and intraretinal hemorrhage (blue overlay) is visible in the region between the optic disc (blue circle) and macula (the macula is not visible, its approximate position is marked with an “M”). The light-yellow spots in the region of the macula indicate exudates and drusen (hatched overlay).

Subretinal and intraretinal hemorrhages can result from pathological neovascularization of the choroid (CNV). The presence of CNV is required for the diagnosis of exudative/wet/neovascular macular degeneration.

D) INCORRECT:

Macular translocation surgery involves detaching the macula from the posterior pole and attaching it to an area of intact retinal pigment epithelium. It can be used as a treatment of last resort for advanced wet AMD in patients with subfoveal neovascularization, edema, and hemorrhages if less invasive therapies have been unsuccessful.

E) INCORRECT:

Photodynamic therapy (PDT) is a second-line treatment for wet AMD that can be used for patients who fail first-line therapy.
questions.hint: This patient's acute, painless, unilateral loss of vision, together with his history of gradual loss of central vision and fundoscopic findings of subretinal hemorrhages and grayish-green retinal discoloration, are characteristic of wet age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Advanced age and smoking are risk factors for this condition.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing blurring of vision in both eyes. The patient says that the blurring has made it difficult to read, although she has noticed that she can read a little better when holding the book below or above eye level. She also requires a bright light to see objects more clearly. She reports that her symptoms began 8 years ago and have gradually gotten worse over time. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide and lisinopril. When looking at an Amsler grid, she says that the lines in the center appear wavy and bent. The results of a funduscopic examination are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic central serous retinopathy (CSR) manifests with progressive blurring of vision and central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing. Hypertension is a risk factor for CSR. Fundoscopy would show elevation of the macula and a halo-like reflex around it; yellow/pale spots on the macula are not consistent with this diagnosis. Finally, CSR most commonly manifests in men between the ages of 20 and 45.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

The macula appears elevated (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

Circle: optic disc

B) INCORRECT:

Uncontrolled hypertension can result in hypertensive retinopathy, which can, in turn, cause progressive impairment of vision, as well as yellow/pale spots on the retina due to soft exudates or hard exudates. However, the spots in this patient are neither soft nor hard exudates. Moreover, in the case of hypertensive retinopathy, other features such as focal attenuation of the arterioles, arteriovenous nicking, and flame-shaped hemorrhage would also be present.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye

There are cotton wool spots (blue overlay), narrow arterioles, and a retinal hemorrhage in close proximity to the papilla (hatched overlay). The papilla shows an unsharply demarcated margin nasally (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line), which is consistent with the diagnosis of papilledema.

These findings are consistent with grade IV hypertensive retinopathy.

M: Macula

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with diabetes mellitus can develop diabetic maculopathy, a severe form of diabetic retinopathy that can cause progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and yellow/pale lesions (hard exudates) on fundoscopy. However, the region of retinal thickening at the macula (the dark red spot) would be larger than one disc diameter (due to macular edema). Also, other features suggestive of diabetic retinopathy, such as microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, and/or cotton wool spots, would usually be present in the remainder of the retina.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

Neovascularization (example indicated by arrowhead) is evident at the temporal superior arcade as tortuous vessels originate from the normal retinal vasculature. Microaneurysms and retinal hemorrhages appear as small red dots and larger red blotches (examples indicated by blue overlay). Hard exudates appear as yellow lesions (examples indicated by green overlay). The retinal veins show periodic dilatations (venous beading; example indicated by yellow overlay).

The diagnosis of proliferative disease requires the presence of neovascularization.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystoid macular edema can present with progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and yellow/pale lesions on fundoscopy. However, these spots would be hard exudates, unlike the drusen seen here, and they are typically arranged in a star-shaped configuration around the macula.

E) INCORRECT:

A senile cataract is an important cause of impaired vision in older individuals. However, a cataract that is severe enough to impair vision would obscure the fundus on ophthalmoscopy and cause a scotoma instead of central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing.

F) INCORRECT:

The incidence of presbyopia increases with age, and patients with presbyopia would have increased difficulty reading. However, the fundal changes seen in this patient are not consistent with presbyopia. Amsler grid testing that is performed in a patient with presbyopia (without applying correction) would result in blurring of all lines/spots instead of central metamorphopsia.

G) INCORRECT:

Doyne's honeycomb macular dystrophy can present with progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and drusen around the macula on fundoscopy. However, the onset of symptoms typically occurs in patients 20–40 years of age. Also, these drusen tend to be arranged radially, in contrast to the drusen in this patient, which are haphazardly arranged around the macula.

H) CORRECT:

The presence of soft drusen near the macula is consistent with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). AMD is the most common cause of impaired vision in older adults in developed countries. Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension increase the risk of AMD. Nonexudative AMD (dry AMD) is the most common type of AMD and leads to a slowly progressive central or pericentral loss of vision. Exudative AMD (wet AMD) makes up 10% of cases and is associated with retinal neovascularization, retinal hemorrhage, and/or loss of vision that progresses more rapidly.
questions.hint: The patient's blurring of central vision and Amsler grid findings indicate central metamorphopsia. The fundoscopy showing multiple yellow areas at the macula confirms the diagnosis. Since these spots do not obscure the retinal vessels, the pathology must be below the nerve fiber layer (i.e., either a hard exudate or a druse but not a cotton wool spot). The clustering of spots around the macula, the absence of sharp margins, and the absence of other retinal pathology indicate that these spots are soft drusen rather than hard exudates.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the abrupt onset of painless loss of vision in his left eye. Over the last several years, he has noticed increased blurring of vision; he says the blurring has made it difficult to read, but he can read better if he holds the book below or above eye level. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Fundoscopic examination shows subretinal fluid and small hemorrhage with grayish-green discoloration in the macular area in the left eye, and multiple drusen in the right eye with retinal pigment epithelial changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's eye condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ustekinumab is a human monoclonal antibody that acts as an antagonist of both interleukin-12 (IL-12) and interleukin-23 (IL-23). Both of these proteins play a role in immune-mediated disorders; IL-12 induces Th1-cell differentiation and IFN-γ production, whereas IL-23 plays a role in controlling TH17 development. Ustekinumab is used in the treatment of psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis, and Crohn disease but not wet age-related macular degeneration.

B) INCORRECT:

Ruxolitinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that acts as a JAK1/2 inhibitor. It is used in the treatment of polycythemia vera; it is not indicated for wet age-related macular degeneration.

C) INCORRECT:

Cetuximab is an epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) inhibitor that is used in the treatment of stage IV colorectal cancer, and head and neck cancers. It is not used for the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration.

D) INCORRECT:

Aldesleukin is a recombinant cytokine that acts as an interleukin-2 (IL-2) analog. It is used in the immunotherapy of renal cell carcinoma and metastatic melanoma. However, it is not used for the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration.

E) INCORRECT:

Etanercept is a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor that acts as a TNF-α decoy receptor. It is mainly used in the treatment of systemic inflammatory illnesses like rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and ankylosing spondylitis. It has no role in the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration.

F) CORRECT:

Ranibizumab is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitor. VEGF release in wet AMD (also referred to as exudative or neovascular AMD) causes choroidal neovascularization with growth of friable blood vessels prone to bleeding and leaking. VEGF inhibitors delivered intravitreally are the first-line treatment for wet AMD and have become the mainstay of treatment due to their efficacy and safety profile.

Dry AMD, the most common form of AMD, involves the deposition of drusen in and under the retinal pigment epithelium. These depositions cause progressive atrophy of the central and/or pericentral retinal pigment epithelium, resulting in painless central and/or pericentral visual impairment.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

Subretinal and intraretinal hemorrhage (blue overlay) is visible in the region between the optic disc (blue circle) and macula (the macula is not visible, its approximate position is marked with an “M”). The light-yellow spots in the region of the macula indicate exudates and drusen (hatched overlay).

Subretinal and intraretinal hemorrhages can result from pathological neovascularization of the choroid (CNV). The presence of CNV is required for the diagnosis of exudative/wet/neovascular macular degeneration.
questions.hint: The patient's acute, painless, unilateral loss of central vision (central scotoma), together with his history of gradual loss of central vision and fundoscopic findings of a subretinal hemorrhage and grayish-green retinal discoloration, are characteristic of wet age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

questions.text: What test is used by patients at home to monitor the progression of macular degeneration?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Humphrey visual-field testing is commonly used to monitor glaucoma and peripheral vision, which is not normally affected by AMD.

B) CORRECT:

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) can lead to macular edema, bleeding, scarring, and atrophy of the macula, which is responsible for central vision. It is the most common cause of blindness in the United States.

Patients with AMD are asked to monitor progression of their disease on a daily basis at home using an Amsler grid. This square grid of black lines on a white background provides information about the patient's central visual field. Patients look at the grid with one eye at a time and identify blurry, wavy, or missing areas. Any change from baseline may indicate worsening AMD and warrants urgent examination by an ophthalmologist.

Key learning point: Self-monitoring of macular degeneration is performed using an Amsler grid. Any change in vision necessitates urgent follow-up with an ophthalmologist.

C) INCORRECT:

Ocular coherence tomography provides detailed information about the layers of the retina and is useful for monitoring AMD. However, it is performed in an office setting, not at home.

D) INCORRECT:

The Snellen chart is used to measure visual acuity (e.g., 20/20). Although patients with AMD may experience a decline in visual acuity, it is more important for them to monitor their central visual field for blurry, wavy, or missing areas on a daily basis.

E) INCORRECT:

Ocular tonometry is used to measure intraocular pressure, which is not affected by AMD and is performed in an office setting, not at home.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of progressive difficulty with her vision. She especially has trouble seeing when she is reading or knitting. She was evaluated by an optometrist one week ago and was prescribed bifocal glasses, but they have not helped.
She had cataract surgery on both eyes 8 years ago.
Direct funduscopy is performed on both the left and right eyes (figures 1 and 2, respectively).
What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Macular degeneration refers to an acquired retinal degeneration that results in central vision loss, typically in patients age 65 or older. It is defined by the presence of numerous drusen and/or retinal pigment epithelial changes in the macula. Over time, macular atrophy (geographic atrophy) or choroidal neovascularization (wet form, related to hemorrhage and fluid) may develop.

Patients with age-related macular degeneration have more difficulty with near-vision tasks, such as reading or knitting, than they do with distance vision. Patients with severe disease may complain of difficulty recognizing faces of people in the room because of a central scotoma.

Bifocal glasses do not improve vision in a patient with macular degeneration.

Direct funduscopy in this patient reveals early geographic atrophy in the right eye and retinal pigment epithelial changes in the left eye. These are characteristic findings attributable to non-neovascular age-related macular degeneration.

Key learning point: In older patients, difficulty with near-vision tasks that does not resolve with bifocal lenses is a hallmark symptom of age-related macular degeneration.

B) INCORRECT:

Posterior capsule opacification is a normal and common cause of decreased vision at all distances after cataract surgery. Glare symptoms often predominate. Posterior capsule opacification may obscure the view of the fundus with the direct ophthalmoscope. Intraocular lens dislocation is a rare complication after cataract surgery; predominant symptoms include glare and visual distortion.

C) INCORRECT:

Neovascular age-related macular degeneration is typically accompanied by retinal swelling and hemorrhage.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with dry eye tend to report ocular surface symptoms, including dryness, irritation, foreign-body sensation, burning sensation, excessive tearing, and fluctuating blurry vision.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary open-angle glaucoma is typically asymptomatic; end-stage disease may be associated with tunnel vision.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the office because of increasing blurring of vision in both eyes. The patient says that the blurring has made it difficult to read, but improves when holding the book below or above eye level. She requires a bright light to see objects more clearly. She reports that her symptoms began 8 years ago and have gradually gotten worse over time. She has hypertension and diabetes mellitus. When looking at an Amsler grid, she says that the lines in the center appear wavy and bent. Fundoscopy shows soft drusen near the macula. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uncontrolled hypertension can result in hypertensive retinopathy, which can, in turn, cause progressive impairment of vision, as well as yellow/pale spots on the retina due to soft exudates or hard exudates. However, the spots in this patient are drusen, not exudates. Moreover, in hypertensive retinopathy, other features such as focal attenuation of the arterioles, arteriovenous nicking, and flame-shaped hemorrhage would also be present.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye

There are cotton wool spots (blue overlay), narrow arterioles, and a retinal hemorrhage in close proximity to the papilla (hatched overlay). The papilla shows an unsharply demarcated margin nasally (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line), which is consistent with the diagnosis of papilledema.

These findings are consistent with grade IV hypertensive retinopathy.

M: Macula

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with diabetes mellitus can develop diabetic maculopathy, a severe form of diabetic retinopathy that can cause progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and yellow/pale lesions (hard exudates) on fundoscopy. However, other features suggestive of diabetic retinopathy, such as microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, and/or cotton wool spots, would usually be present.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

Neovascularization (example indicated by arrowhead) is evident at the temporal superior arcade as tortuous vessels originate from the normal retinal vasculature. Microaneurysms and retinal hemorrhages appear as small red dots and larger red blotches (examples indicated by blue overlay). Hard exudates appear as yellow lesions (examples indicated by green overlay). The retinal veins show periodic dilatations (venous beading; example indicated by yellow overlay).

The diagnosis of proliferative disease requires the presence of neovascularization.

C) INCORRECT:

A senile cataract is an important cause of impaired vision in older individuals. However, a cataract that is severe enough to impair vision would obscure the fundus on ophthalmoscopy and cause a scotoma instead of central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing.

D) INCORRECT:

The incidence of presbyopia increases with age, and patients with presbyopia would have increased difficulty reading. However, the fundal changes seen in this patient are not consistent with presbyopia. Amsler grid testing that is performed in a patient with presbyopia (without applying correction) would result in blurring of all lines/spots instead of central metamorphopsia.

E) CORRECT:

The presence of soft drusen near the macula is consistent with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). AMD is the most common cause of impaired vision in older adults in developed countries. Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension increase the risk of AMD. Nonexudative AMD (dry AMD) is the most common type of AMD and leads to a slowly progressive central or pericentral loss of vision. Exudative AMD (wet AMD) makes up 10% of cases and is associated with retinal neovascularization, retinal hemorrhage, and/or loss of vision that progresses more rapidly.
questions.hint: The patient's Amsler grid findings indicate central metamorphopsia.

He has noticed progressive bilateral loss of central vision over the last year. During this time, he has had difficulty reading the newspaper and watching television. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. Fundoscopic examination shows subretinal fluid and small hemorrhages with grayish-green discoloration in the macular area in the right eye, and multiple drusen in the left eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors (e.g., etanercept) are used in the treatment of systemic inflammatory illnesses like rheumatoid arthritis. It has no role in the treatment of wet AMD yet. However, there are ongoing investigations that test the use intravitreal TNF-alpha inhibitors for the treatment of vascular and neovascular retinal diseases (e.g., wet AMD).

Thermal laser photocoagulation (retinal photocoagulation) can be used to coagulate the abnormal choroidal neovascular membrane in wet AMD. However, laser photocoagulation can also damage the overlying retina and may result in a permanent blind spot. Newer options with better efficacy and safety profiles are available and should be attempted first.

C) CORRECT:

Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitors (e.g., ranibizumab, bevacizumab) delivered via intravitreal injection are the first-line treatment for wet AMD. These substances inhibit the growth of new, friable blood vessels in the choriocapillaris, which are prone to bleeding and leaking. Second-line treatment options for wet AMD include photodynamic therapy and laser photocoagulation. Smoking cessation, hypertension control, and antioxidant vitamin supplementation are recommended for both dry and wet AMD.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

Subretinal and intraretinal hemorrhage (blue overlay) is visible in the region between the optic disc (blue circle) and macula (the macula is not visible, its approximate position is marked with an “M”). The light-yellow spots in the region of the macula indicate exudates and drusen (hatched overlay).

Subretinal and intraretinal hemorrhages can result from pathological neovascularization of the choroid (CNV). The presence of CNV is required for the diagnosis of exudative/wet/neovascular macular degeneration.

Photodynamic therapy (PDT) is a second-line treatment for wet AMD that can be used for patients who fail first-line therapy.

Advanced age and smoking are risk factors for this condition.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to your clinic because of progressively worsening blurred vision in both eyes. She reports difficulty reading, which improves when she holds the book below or above eye level, and she needs a bright light to see objects more clearly. Her symptoms began 8 years ago and have gradually worsened. She has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. When viewing an Amsler grid, she notes that the lines in the center appear wavy and bent. Fundoscopic examination reveals soft drusen near the macula. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The incidence of presbyopia increases with age, and patients with presbyopia would have increased difficulty reading. However, the fundal changes seen in this patient are not consistent with presbyopia. Amsler grid testing that is performed in a patient with presbyopia (without applying correction) would result in blurring of all lines/spots instead of central metamorphopsia.

B) INCORRECT:

A senile cataract is an important cause of impaired vision in older individuals. However, a cataract that is severe enough to impair vision would obscure the fundus on ophthalmoscopy and cause a scotoma instead of central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing.

C) CORRECT:

The presence of soft drusen near the macula is consistent with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). AMD is the most common cause of impaired vision in older adults in developed countries. Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension increase the risk of AMD. Nonexudative AMD (dry AMD) is the most common type of AMD and leads to a slowly progressive central or pericentral loss of vision. Exudative AMD (wet AMD) makes up 10% of cases and is associated with retinal neovascularization, retinal hemorrhage, and/or loss of vision that progresses more rapidly.

Key learning point: Age-related macular degeneration is characterized by gradual central vision loss and drusen near the macula, making it the leading cause of vision impairment in older adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with diabetes mellitus can develop diabetic maculopathy, a severe form of diabetic retinopathy that can cause progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and yellow/pale lesions (hard exudates) on fundoscopy. However, other features suggestive of diabetic retinopathy, such as microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, and/or cotton wool spots, would usually be present.

E) INCORRECT:

Uncontrolled hypertension can result in hypertensive retinopathy, which can, in turn, cause progressive impairment of vision, as well as yellow/pale spots on the retina due to soft exudates or hard exudates. However, the spots in this patient are drusen, not exudates. Moreover, in hypertensive retinopathy, other features such as focal attenuation of the arterioles, arteriovenous nicking, and flame-shaped hemorrhage would also be present.
questions.hint: The patient's Amsler grid findings indicate central metamorphopsia.
